title: DTC children’s food brand Little Spoon expands with breakfast SKUs, Oatly collaboration
summary: Little Spoon, a direct-to-consumer brand specializing in organic baby and toddler food, has expanded its product line to include breakfast options due to customer demand for quick and healthy meals. The company, which is profitable and has raised $90 million in funding, is committed to its DTC model but acknowledges potential opportunities in retail. Little Spoon's new breakfast products include bite-sized options with protein and an overnight oat smoothie in collaboration with Oatly.
product_or_process: Breakfast products like Pesto Eggs Biteable, Mini Classic Eggs + Sausage Biteable, The Classic Breakfast Plate, and overnight oat smoothies

greenwashing: The article doesn't mention any claims about the environmental benefits of the products, so it's not an example of greenwashing.

title: Watch on demand: How can plant-based protein win over consumers, retailers ‘burned’ by past experiences with the category?
summary: Plant-based meat sales are declining as consumers are dissatisfied with the taste and price of current offerings. To revive the category, companies like Jack & Annie's and MyForest Foods are focusing on creating high-quality products with whole ingredients and appealing nutritional profiles. Retailers are also urged to proactively support plant-based meat offerings with merchandising strategies that highlight their benefits.
likely_naics_codes: ['311111 - Meat Packing Plants', '311991 - Other Food Manufacturing', '445110 - Supermarkets and Other Grocery (except Convenience) Stores', '424410 - Grocery and Related Product Wholesalers']
greenwashing: The article does not suggest any greenwashing activities by the companies mentioned, highlighting their emphasis on product quality and ingredient transparency.

title: Butyl Rubber Market Poised For Steady Growth Driven By Automotive And Pharmaceutical Demands
summary: The global butyl rubber market is expected to grow significantly in the coming years, driven by increasing demand from the automotive and pharmaceutical sectors. The market is characterized by several key players who are developing innovative products and processes, including eco-friendly alternatives and enhanced performance features.

title: Do consumers believe ‘better-for-you’ marketing on snacks?
summary: The article discusses the growing popularity of functional foods, claiming to offer health benefits, and the food industry's efforts to regain consumer trust. Consumers are increasingly skeptical of health claims and prefer products with transparent labeling and recognizable ingredients. The industry is responding with initiatives like clean label products, standardized nutritional information, and a focus on natural ingredients, aiming to improve transparency and regain consumer confidence.
product_or_process: Functional foods, clean label products, standardized nutritional information

title: How brands are capitalising on gut health
summary: The gut health trend is booming, driven by increased consumer awareness and interest in products promoting digestive health.  Manufacturers are capitalizing on this trend by developing a range of gut-friendly food and beverage products, from probiotic milk drinks to fermented beverages and quinoa-based baby foods.  This trend shows no signs of slowing down, with continued growth expected in the market for everyday gut health support products.
product_or_process: carrots as a gut health ingredient
